Key Arguments: The Bill threatens democratic rights by allowing the government to define truth and enforce it, exempting itself and mainstream media.
The subjective definition of misinformation and disinformation by ACMA leaves room for abuse of power and suppresses public debate.
The Bill enables tech companies to act as tools of government censorship, stifling free speech.
It promotes ideological conformity, suppressing dissenting voices and hindering independent thought.
The Bill lacks sufficient accountability and oversight for misuse of censorship powers.
The penalties for non-compliance are excessive and create a chilling effect on free speech.
The Bill's exclusion of government-authorized content is hypocritical and inconsistent.
Notable Quotes: The proposed Combating Misinformation and Disinformation Bill threatens the very essence of our democratic rights.
The Bill effectively enables tech companies to become tools of government censorship, stifling free speech and undermining the open exchange of ideas.
The Bill paves the way for ideological conformity, suppressing dissenting voices and hindering independent thought.
The Bill puts too much power in the hands of unelected bureaucrats to silence speech in the public square without transparency or accountability.
